./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Introduction
Reaction is an F# implementation of Async Observables (ReactiveX) and was designed spesifically for targeting Fable which means that the code may be transpiled to JavaScript, and thus the same F# code may be used both client and server side for full stack software development.
See Fable Reaction for Elmish-ish use of Reaction.

pages/Install.html.title: Install
pages/Install.html.body:
Install
Reaction is available as a NuGet package for NETStandard 2.0. There is a dependency for FSharp.Control.AsyncSeq, but only when used on .NET (not Fable).
paket add Reaction --project

pages/GettingStarted.html.title: Getting Started

pages/Types.html.title: Types and Interfaces
pages/Types.html.body:
Types
Reaction is built around the interfaces IAsyncDisposable, IAsyncObserver and IAsyncObservable. This enables a familiar Rx programming syntax similar to FSharp.Control.Reactive with the difference that all methods are Async.
type IAsyncDisposable =
    abstract member DisposeAsync: unit -> Async

type IAsyncObserver =
    abstract member OnNextAsync: 'a -> Async
    abstract member OnErrorAsync: exn -> Async
    abstract member OnCompletedAsync: unit -> Async

type IAsyncObservable =
    abstract member SubscribeAsync: IAsyncObserver -> Async

The relationship between these three interfaces can be seen in this single line of code. You get an async disposable by subscribing asynchronously to an async observable with an async observer:
async {
    let! disposableAsync = observable.SubscribeAsync observerAsync
    ...
}

Notifications
Observers may written as a function accepting Notification which is defined as the following discriminated union:
type Notification =
    | OnNext of 'a
    | OnError of exn
    | OnCompleted

pages/Observers.html.title: Observers

pages/Observables.html.title: Observables
pages/Observables.html.body:
Async Observables
Reaction is an implementation of Async Observable. The difference between an "Async Observable" and an "Observable" is that with "Async Observables" you need to await methods such as Subscribe, OnNext, OnError, and OnCompleted. In Reaction they are thus called SubscribeAsync, OnNextAsync, OnErrorAsync, and OnCompletedAsync. This enables SubscribeAsync to await async operations i.e setup network connections, and observers (OnNext) may finally await side effects such as writing to disk (observers are all about side-effects right?).
This diagram shows the how Async Observables relates to other collections and values.




Single Value
Multiple Values




Synchronous pull
unit -> 'a
seq


Synchronous push
'a -> unit
Observable


Asynchronous pull
unit -> Async
AsyncSeq


Asynchronous push
'a -> Async\
AsyncObservable

pages/Streams.html.title: Streams
pages/Streams.html.body:
The Stream
You can think of a Stream as being a tube that is open at both sides. Streams implement both the IAsyncObservable and IAsyncObserver interfaces. Whatever you put in at one side (IAsyncObserver) will come out of the other end (IAsyncObservable).
Streams and are similar to the classic Subject in ReactiveX. The difference is that a Stream in Reaction is not a single object, but a tuple of two entangled objects where one implements IAsyncObserver, and the other implements IAsyncObservable. This solves the problem of having a single object trying to be two things at once (what is the dual of an ISubject anyways?).
Stream
The stream will forward any notification pushed to the IAsyncObserver side to all observers that have subscribed to the IAsyncObservable side. The stream is hot in the sense that if there are no observers, then the notification will be lost.

stream : unit -> IAsyncObserver * IAsyncObservable

let dispatch, obs = stream ()

let main = async {
    let! sub = obs.SubscribeAsync obv
    do! dispatch.OnNextAsync 42
    ...
}

Async.StartImmediate main ()

Mailbox Stream
Same as a stream except that the observer is exposed as a MailboxProcessor>. The mailbox stream is hot in the sense that if there are no observers, then any pushed notification will be lost.

mbStream : unit -> MailboxProcessor> * IAsyncObservable

let dispatch, obs = mbStream ()

let main = async {
    let! sub = obs.SubscribeAsync obv
    do dispatch.Post (OnNext 42)
    ...
}

Async.StartImmediate main ()

Single Stream
The stream will forward any notification pushed to the IAsyncObserver side to a single observer that have subscribed to the IAsyncObservable side. The single stream is "cold" in the sense that if there's no-one observing, then the writer will be awaited until there is a subscriber that can observe the value being pushed. You can use a single stream in scenarios that requires so called backpressure.

singleStream : unit -> IAsyncObserver * IAsyncObservable

pages/Operators.html.title: Operators
pages/Operators.html.body:
Operators
The following parameterized async observerable returning functions (operators) are
currently supported. Other operators may be implemented on-demand, but the goal is to keep it simple
and not make this into a full featured ReactiveX implementation (if possible).
Create
Functions for creating ('a -> IAsyncObservable) an async observable.

empty : unit -> IAsyncObservable
single : 'a -> IAsyncObservable
fail : exn -> IAsyncObservable
defer : (unit -> IAsyncObservable) -> IAsyncObservable
create : (AsyncObserver\ -> Async\) -> IAsyncObservable
ofSeq : seq -> IAsyncObservable
ofAsyncSeq : AsyncSeq -> IAsyncObservable (Not available in Fable)
timer : int -> IAsyncObservable\
interval int -> IAsyncObservable\

Transform
Functions for transforming (IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable) an async observable.

map : ('a -> 'b) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
mapi : ('a*int -> 'b) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
mapAsync : ('a -> Async) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
mapiAsync : ('a*int -> Async) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMap : ('a -> IAsyncObservable) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMapi : ('a*int -> IAsyncObservable) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMapAsync : ('a -> Async\\>) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMapiAsync : ('a*int -> Async\\>) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMapLatest : ('a -> IAsyncObservable) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMapLatestAsync : ('a -> Async\\>) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
catch : (exn -> IAsyncObservable) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Filter
Functions for filtering (IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable) an async observable.

filter : ('a -> bool) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
filterAsync : ('a -> Async\) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
distinctUntilChanged : IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
takeUntil : IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
choose : ('a -> 'b option) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
chooseAsync : ('a -> Async) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Aggregate

scan : 's -> ('s -> 'a -> 's) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
scanAsync : 's -> ('s -> 'a -> Async) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
groupBy : ('a -> 'g) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable\>

Combine
Functions for combining multiple async observables into one.

merge : IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
mergeInner : IAsyncObservable> -> IAsyncObservable
switchLatest : IAsyncObservable> -> IAsyncObservable
concat : seq> -> IAsyncObservable
startWith : seq -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
combineLatest : IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
withLatestFrom : IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
zipSeq : seq -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Time-shift
Functions for time-shifting (IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable) an async observable.

delay : int -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
debounce : int -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Leave
Functions for leaving (IAsyncObservable -> 'a) the async observable.
-- toAsyncSeq : IAsyncObservable -> AsyncSeq (Not available in Fable)

pages/Query.html.title: Query Builder
pages/Query.html.body:
Query Builder
Queries may be written by composing functions or using query expressions. Thus the two examples below are equivalent:
Seq.toList "TIME FLIES LIKE AN ARROW"
|> Seq.mapi (fun i c -> i, c)
|> ofSeq
|> flatMap (fun (i, c) ->
    fromMouseMoves ()
    |> delay (100 * i)
    |> map (fun m -> Letter (i, string c, int m.clientX, int m.clientY)))

The above query may be written in query expression style:
reaction {
    let! i, c = Seq.toList "TIME FLIES LIKE AN ARROW"
                |> Seq.mapi (fun i c -> i, c)
                |> ofSeq
    let ms = fromMouseMoves () |> delay (100 * i)
    for m in ms do
        yield Letter (i, string c, int m.clientX, int m.clientY)
}

extras/Giraffe.html.title: Giraffe Middleware
extras/Giraffe.html.body:
Reaction Middleware for Giraffe
The Reaction Middleware for Giraffe is an experimental support for server side WebSocket message handling.
Install
> paket add Reaction.Giraffe --project 

Getting Started
You add the Reaction middleware to Giraffe using the UseReaction method on the IApplicationBuilder in the configureApp function of the Giraffe setup.
let query (connectionId: ConnectionId) (msgs: IAsyncObservable) : IAsyncObservable =
    msgs
    |> filter (fun (msg, cId) -> cId = connectionId)

let configureApp (app : IApplicationBuilder) =
    app.UseWebSockets()
       .UseReaction(fun options ->
       { options with
           Query = query
           Encode = Msg.Encode
           Decode = Msg.Decode
       })
       .UseDefaultFiles()
       .UseStaticFiles()
       .UseGiraffe webApp

Options
Options may be overrided by UseReaction.
[]
type ReactionConfig =
    {
        QueryAll: IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
        Query: ConnectionId -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
        Encode: 'msg -> string
        Decode: string -> 'msg option
        RequestPath: string
    }

Query
A query for the stream of messages to a given client. The type of the query is ConnectionId -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable.
The query function takes a connectionId and an AsyncObservable. The connectionId is the id for a particualar clients connection. Messages that leaves in the returned observable will only go to that particular client. Notifications will be a tuple 'msg*ConnectionId where 'msg is the message being handled and the connectionId is the client connection where this message was received.
Thus this query will only send messages back to the same client that sent them. Messages for other clients will be filtered.
let query (connectionId: ConnectionId) (msgs: IAsyncObservable) : IAsyncObservable =
    msgs
    |> filter (fun (msg, cId) -> cId = connectionId)

This query will only send back messages from other clients. Messages that the client sent itself will be filtered.
let query (connectionId: ConnectionId) (msgs: IAsyncObservable) : IAsyncObservable =
    msgs
    |> filter (fun (msg, cId) -> cId <> connectionId)

QueryAll
This query is of type IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable and is a query for the single stream of all messages to and from all clients. This query is processed first, and enables us to send messages that needs to be received by all clients. Thus we may produce messages out of thin air (timers etc) and send them to all connected clients.
Encode
Encoder for serializing a message to JSON string. The type of encoder is 'msg -> string.
Decode
Decoder for deserializing a JSON string to a message. The type of decoder is string -> 'msg option.
RequestPath
Request path where the server will liste for websocket requests. Default is /ws. You will usually not need to change this.
